abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Polychlorinated
            Biphenyls (PCB) Management and Disposal Demonstration
            Project for China were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to global environment outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned include: at the project design stage, in
            situations where baseline data such as the number of sites
            contaminated, the extent of site specific contamination, and
            the level of clean-up required, is either difficult to
            determine or simply not known, outcome indicators developed
            should err towards the conservative, to avoid setting overly
            ambitious targets that may require downgrading through
            time-consuming restructuring in future. It is key to begin
            work early on a clear plan for immediate next steps involved
            in the application of a national PCB replication program,
            endorsed by relevant government and private sector partners,
            and ensure the ongoing use of high-value project inputs,
            such as the thermal desorption unit (TDU). Effective PCB
            management in accordance with Stockholm convention
            guidelines involves treatment and disposal using technology
            that meets best available techniques and best environmental
            practices. When investing in such technology, thorough and
            comprehensive prior assessment must be undertaken on the
            proposed alternatives. Retrofitting one national service
            provider to a level that meets international standards while
            national standards remain less stringent does not
            incentivize use of the upgraded facility. In projects where
            legal dispensation is required to carry out work (licensing
            or permitting), it is vital that the relevant legal
            requirements be clearly understood and the centers of
            authorization engaged from the outset of a project. Bank
            supervision teams must ensure that local project partners
            possess the knowledge and capacity required to manage
            complex procurement actions effectively. Projects that
            require extensive technical management must include specific
            training to build such capacity so that smooth and efficient
            processing ensues.
